results.title: Chemical evolution
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Origin of Life”.
Evidence supporting evolution of life in the primordial sea is the basis for the film’s content. Actual footage of scientific investigations is featured. These include: Russian biochemist - AI Oparin; Dr Stanley Miller and Dr Cyril Ponnamperuma. We also see a miniature amino acid analyser and other complex analytical apparatus at NASA’s Ames Research Centre.

results.title: Chemical equilibrium
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
These episodes examine the theory of steady state, dynamic equilibrium, kinetic molecular theory, reaction tendencies and the equilibrium constant. Illustrates forward and reverse reactions of various chemical changes including the production of hydrogen iodide, hydrogen chloride and ammonia. Finally, through demonstrations of Le Chatlier’s principle and the Haber process, students gain a better understanding of the importance of chemical equilibrium. The episodes are “Unsteady steadiness”, “Dynamic equilibrium”, Reaction kinetics”, “The Equilibrium constant” mand “The Haber process

results.title: Chemical bond and atomic structure
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chemistry”.
Discusses the structure of the atom and shows how the electrons help determine the way in which the atom bonds chemically with other atoms. Shows three types of chemical bonding and explains how bonding affects substance. (Suitable for years 11-12)

results.title: Chelsea College
results.brief_description: This film concerns the theoretical and practical instruction received by students at the College of Aeronautics and Automobile Engineering in Chelsea, England, and the practical application of their highly skilled technical knowledge in many fields of present day life. The students coming from over forty-five different countries are divided into three training groups - automobile, aeronautical, and agricultural engineering. In addition to showing a good deal of detail of the training given, the film displays scenes of the student life out of the class-rooms.

results.title: Cheetah
results.creator_credit: Jane Chermayeff, Peter Chermayeff and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Examines, without commentary, the physical characteristics and behavior of African animals in their natural environment, including the fleeting cheetah in action on the Serengeti Plains of Tanzania as it hunts its favourite prey, the Thompson’s gazelle. Develops skills of self expression and encourages independent thought in relating visual experiences to creative activities. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Chasing lizards
results.creator_credit: Alan Mitchell and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Threatening nightmares plague a young man who is still disturbed by an uncomfortable incident in his childhood. With the encouragement of his lover he locates his would-be assailant, searching for an end to his depressive madness.

results.title: Chasing Buddha
results.creator_credit: Amiel Courtin-Wilson, Julie Stone, Film Victoria, Go>Group, Halo and SBS Independent
results.brief_description: Compelling and informative, “Chasing Buddha” is a biographical documentary about Robina Courtin, a highly energetic, outrageous, radical feminist, lesbian Australian Buddhist nun. Born one of seven children and raised as a Catholic, Robina candidly tells of her journey from childhood through to her teens and adult life and of the uncontained energy that drove her into becoming a political activist and radical feminist during the 70s, and finally the “accidental” path which lead her to Buddhism and to her Llama. Loud, enigmatic, charismatic, this amazing woman spends most of her time in the United States where she runs an international magazine, Mandala, teaches and councils students in Buddhism and visits prisoners on life sentences or on death row offering them spiritual guidance and the teachings of Buddha. Totally committed in her beliefs but not afraid to be outspoken or even confrontational, Robina has won the hearts of many and is highly respected wherever she goes. Includes narratives by family and friends, stills, home movies and archival footage. Director Amiel Courtin-Wilson, Robina’s nephew, was nominated in the AFI Awards (2000) for Best Direction in a Documentary.

results.title: Charlie needs a cloak
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: Charlie is a shepherd. He has a cosy house, a big hat, a crook, a flock of fat sheep - and a tattered cloak. In the springtime, Charlie decides to make himself a new red cloak. He shears his sheep and fashions his new garment from the wool. This animated film, sparked by a whimsical Italian tarantella musical score, follows the process of making woollen cloth into clothing with charm and wry humour. The conclusion will delight - and not altogether surprise - the young viewer. Written and animated by Tomie de Paola from his book of the same name.

results.title: Charlie Chaplin: The Adventurer/the Cure
results.brief_description: Charles Chaplin was born on April 6, 1889 in South London of not so successful music hall entertainers. At the age of eight he joined a variety act called “The Eight Lancashire Lads” and worked all over England and parts of Europe throughout his childhood. He toured America in 1910-11 and returned to that country again in 1912 to 1913 where he was seen by Mack Sennett and joined the Keystone company for $150 per week. This cassette features: “The Cure” (1917) and “The Adventurer” (1917).
